summary: clinically, respiratory viral infections are often implicated as triggers of CRS flare-ups (2, 3) respiratory viral infections are often implicated as triggers of CRS flare-ups. some experimental studies have suggested an important role for viral pathogens during the exacerbation and ongoing inflammation in CRS (4–8) the prevalence of viral pathogens in CRS patients with no signs of acute viral infection was investigated in this prospective study using multiplex PCR assay. the respiratory virus infection rate in CRS patients was compared with that in control subjects. the study was approved by the Institutional Review Board of the Asan Medical Center (Seoul, South Korea) all adult participants and legally authorized representatives of children provided informed consent. nasal lavage and scrapes of the nasal epithelium were collected immediately after general anesthesia. RNA was extracted from 140 l of each respiratory sample using a QIAamp viral RNA kit (Qiagen, GmbH, Hilden, Germany) to synthesize cDNA, reverse transcription was performed using a RevertAid first-strand cDNA synthesis kit (Fermentas, Burlington, ON, Canada), according to the manufacturer's instructions. coronaviruses 229E/NL63 and OC43, adenovirus, human metapneumovirus (HMPV) and human bocaviruses 1, 2, 3, and 4 were visualized by electrophoresis on agarose gel. the multiplex PCR products were visualized by electrophoresis on 2% agarose gel. patients with fungal sinusitis, current immunotherapy, aspirin desensitization, or cystic fibrosis were excluded from this study. the presence of sinusitis in the control group was ruled out based on their history, physical examination, plain sinus X-ray, and computed tomography (CT imaging) samples were collected from all participants from summer 2011 to spring 2012 for 8 months. sample size was approximately equally distributed over the months. mucosal scraping was found to be more sensitive than nasal lavage for viral detection. each cDNA was subjected to multiplex PCR using a Seeplex RV15 ACE detection kit. 3 l of synthesized first-strand cDNA, 5 RV15 primer mix, 2 multiplex master mix and 3 l 8-methoxypsoralen (8-MOP) solution were mixed. multiplex PCR products were visualized by electrophoresis on 2% agarose gel. target size in agarose gel (bp) RV15 ACE detection (set A) this study included 62 (55.9%) CRS patients with nasal polyps. there was no association of asthma, allergic rhinitis, and nasal polyps with respiratory virus detection rate or multiple virus detection. there was no statistically significant difference related to the age of the patients in which viruses were detected. in 56 (50.5%) of the nasal lavage samples from the 111 CRS patients and 14 (28.0%) of the control subjects, there were significant differences in the overall virus detection rates between the two groups. coinfections with >1 virus was detected in 27 (24.3%) of the CRS patients. the detection rates for influenza, RSV, coronavirus 229E and OC43, adenovirus, enterovirus, HMPV, and human bocavirus did not differ between the CRS and control groups. the detection rate in CRS patients is significantly greater than that in controls (P 0.01).
